skill.name: cass
skill.description: Coding Agent Session Search - unified CLI/TUI to index and search local coding agent history from Claude Code, Codex, Gemini, Cursor, Aider, ChatGPT, Pi-Agent, Factory, and more. Purpose-built for AI agent consumption with robot mode.
skill.summary: Unified CLI/TUI to index and search local coding agent history from Claude Code, Codex, Gemini, Cursor, and other AI coding tools.
skill.author: Dicklesworthstone

security_audit.summary: Legitimate developer tool for indexing and searching coding agent session history. Static findings are false positives: shell backticks in documentation examples, AES-256-GCM encryption documentation, and standard dev path access for indexing. No malicious intent detected.

content.value_statement: Developers lose track of solutions found by AI coding assistants. This tool indexes sessions from Claude Code, Codex, Gemini, Cursor, and 8+ other agents into a unified searchable database.
actual_capabilities: Index sessions from 11+ AI coding agents (Claude Code, Codex, Gemini CLI, Cursor, Aider, ChatGPT, and more)
Search across all agent sessions with JSON output designed for AI consumption
Export conversations to markdown, HTML, or JSON format
Connect remote machines via SSH to search sessions across multiple computers
Timeline view to review daily or weekly agent activity
limitations: Requires local agent session data to be present on disk
ChatGPT v2/v3 encryption requires keychain access for indexing
Semantic search requires manual model installation
TUI mode blocks terminal; must use --robot flag for automation

use_cases.title: Find past solutions
use_cases.description: Search your entire agent history to find solutions you discovered before. Query by error message, function name, or concept.
use_cases.target_user: Developers working with AI coding assistants

use_cases.title: Cross-agent research
use_cases.description: Compare how different AI agents approached the same problem. See patterns in their solutions and learn from their different strategies.

use_cases.title: Team handoff
use_cases.description: Share relevant past sessions with team members. Export context so the next agent understands what has already been tried.
use_cases.target_user: Development teams using multiple AI tools

prompt_templates.title: Basic search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search my agent sessions for solutions related to #{query}. Use cass search "#{query}" --robot --limit 10 --days 30. Report any relevant code patterns or commands that worked.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to find how you solved a similar problem before

prompt_templates.title: Error resolution
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all sessions where I dealt with #{error_type}. Use cass search "#{error_type}" --robot --fields summary. Show me the approaches that succeeded.
prompt_templates.scenario: When encountering a new error and wanting to see past solutions

prompt_templates.title: Timeline review
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me my agent activity for today. Use cass timeline --today --json --group-by hour. Summarize what I worked on.
prompt_templates.scenario: When reviewing daily progress or documenting work

prompt_templates.title: Agent comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare how Claude Code and Cursor handled #{topic}. Search both agents separately and show me their different approaches.
prompt_templates.scenario: When comparing strategies across different AI coding tools

output_examples.output:
Found 3 relevant sessions:
1. Claude Code: Created interface for API response (src/api/types.ts:15)
2. Cursor: Added type guards for user input (lib/validation.ts:42)
3. Aider: Refactored to use discriminated unions (types/events.ts:8)

Timeline (Today - 6 hours of activity):
09:00-10:00: Database schema design (Claude Code)
10:00-11:00: API endpoint implementation (Cursor)
11:00-12:00: Authentication tests (Aider)

best_practices: Run cass index --full after installing to ensure complete session coverage
Use --robot flag for all AI-to-AI interactions to get structured JSON output
Enable watch mode (cass index --watch) for real-time indexing during development
Configure remote sources to search sessions from all your development machines
anti_patterns: Running cass without --robot flag in automated workflows (blocks terminal)
Skipping regular indexing after agent session data changes
Using imprecise search terms that return too many unrelated results
Ignoring the --limit flag when working with limited token budgets

faq.question: Which agents does CASS support?
faq.answer: CASS supports Claude Code, Codex, Gemini CLI, Cline, OpenCode, Amp, Cursor, ChatGPT, Aider, Pi-Agent, and Factory (Droid). Each agent's sessions are stored in their native format and location.

faq.question: How does robot mode differ from TUI mode?
faq.answer: Robot mode (--robot flag) outputs structured JSON designed for AI consumption. TUI mode launches an interactive terminal interface for human users. Always use --robot in automated workflows.

faq.question: Can CASS search remote machines?
faq.answer: Yes, CASS supports remote sources via SSH. Run cass sources setup to discover hosts from ~/.ssh/config, then sync sessions from remote machines to search locally.

faq.question: What happens to encrypted ChatGPT sessions?
faq.answer: ChatGPT v2/v3 uses AES-256-GCM encryption with keys stored in the macOS keychain. CASS can only index these if keychain access is granted. Legacy v1 sessions are unencrypted and indexed automatically.

faq.question: Does CASS send data to the cloud?
faq.answer: No, CASS is a local-only tool. All indexing and searching happens on your machine. Semantic search models must be installed manually and never downloaded automatically.

faq.question: How much disk space does indexing require?
faq.answer: CASS uses SQLite for the index (typically 10-50MB for extensive histories) and stores minimal metadata. Your original agent session files remain unchanged.
